author: potuz
content:
People that don't run nodes don't get to even be exposed to "safe" they only get to see the results of it: their transaction appears as confirmed in some UX when it may not really be, the price they are seeing in another app is not really the right one, etc.  

The advantage on the node operator being able to change it is that it's really the freedom to do so: if I'm processing deposits for a dapp and I'm tracking live all attestations and I see all blocks since finalized full and all attestations present and I'm on slot 20 of the epoch I feel pretty confident that slot 0 is safe. The current algorithm, even using unrealized justification, will only deem that slot safe 12 seconds later.  Those 12 seconds may mean a lot to some users. Who am I to restrict their usage of the network? Why should we decide for them what's safe or not?

author: sky.cactus
content: If you know enough to change what `safe` points to, then you can just use one of the other tags directly.  The purpose of `safe` is to give a reasonable default to people who don't know the difference between `latest`, `confirmed`, `justified`, `finalized`.  It is meant to be a signal that "for the majority of people, this is a safe enough tag to use".

author: sky.cactus
content: If client operators are changing it, then users of those clients will end up getting different behavior (confusing) depending on what JSON-RPC endpoint you select, and your level of safety will also change unexpectedly.

author: sky.cactus
content: `safe` is essentially "people with a very deep understanding of the protocol have thought long and hard about this and believe that for most use cases, the `safe` tag is safe to use for just about anything."

author: sky.cactus
content: For this to work, safe needs to be consistent between JSON-RPC endpoints, otherwise you are delegating decision making to some other party who may have other incentives and probably hasn't thought about this as much as the core developers.
